dialogues.SHANE:
[1]And you look like that coach from the Seventies. From the Redskins. McGinty. Except you look a shitload older. The price of happiness. Something to take the chill off? I'm running the Redskins again. And I want you to quarterback 'em. 
[2]No, man, I've been out way too long. What, three years since San Diego dumped you? That's nothing. You're in shape, flopping around in the water like that. 
[3]You know what my nickname was in San Diego, don't you? Sure.   Footsteps. 
[4]As in, I hear 'em and I dump the ball. Well, you didn't have much of a line to protect you.

[6]No kidding? Oh, you had a lot of tools: a quick release. Fast. A scrambler by nature. Good downfield vision. But you got hurt a lot. And worst of all, you never could win the big game. What did you lose the Sugar Bowl by, your senior year? What, forty points? 
[7]Forty-five. And now you want to recruit me? A scrambling quarterback is gonna do real well in this new replacement environment. And to tell you the truth, I think I can help you with your biggest problem. 
[8]Okay.   What's my biggest problem? Courage. I think that Sugar Bowl took it all out of you. 
[9]I'm retired from football. Yeah, and it looks like things have been going really well for you since. 
[10]I like being here. It's quiet. I like being alone. Yeah. No screaming crowds, that's for sure. You know what separates the winners from the losers? Gettin' back on the horse. The one that kicked you in the teeth. You're still young. You still got bags of talent. If you do well, who knows what will happen when the strike ends? You want me to tell you you're not going to get hurt? You know you will. No doubt about that. But, hell... ... Wouldn't you rather get hurt than scrape the shit off of other guys' toys?

That's the sure sign of a loser. From there, it wasn't very far to thinking that I'll never win, that I didn't deserve to win at anything. Including love.

It's important that you leave here, however, with the knowledge that you have made a difference in your own life, in the owner's life -- or what's left of it -- and especially the fans'. You have proven to a skeptical America that sports is not about contracts, or agents or shoe deals. Sports is about rising to the occasion. We have one more opportunity tonight to do that, one more chance to show what heart is all about. The Dallas Cowboys are waiting out there to kill you. I expect nothing less than for you to win even in your death throes. We have a powerful weapon on our side tonight: there is no tomorrow for most of you. And that makes you very dangerous people. Use it.

[7]Good. Remember: anything. You got it? Okay? ... because it's a damn waste of all that speed, Clifford. I told you that when you were in high school. You've got to catch the ball, son. This is the main idea of the passing game. 
[8]You would think he's done enough. 
[9]McGinty, I mean.

[11]Like    after that Sugar Bowl    game? I guess you could    survive anything after    that. 
[12]My dad. He's a huge Redskin fan. For years. He's in his twenty-ninth year at the Senate Office Building. As a guard, not a senator. The only thing that keeps him going he says, is me and the Redskins. That's where I get it. My fan-ness. Are you scared? 
[13]It's okay. Anybody would be. But you're good. And you'll do good.

dialogues.O'NEIL:
[1]If you keep talking to me like I'm a five- year-old, I'm going to hurt you. 
[2]What the fuck was that?! 
[3]Bullshit he slipped! He could have scored! Anybody could have scored! I got one foot in the god damn grave and I could have scored! 
[4]You god damn wimp! You're fired! Get out! Get out! Get out! 
[5]Get me Jimmy McGinty. Get him here. Tonight. 
[6]I'm dying, Jimmy. You been dying for twenty years. That poof of a nurse of yours is gonna kick my ass if he catches you drinking. 
[7]Gimme a butt. I quit. 
[8]No. 
[9]You pussy. I want you to come back as head coach. I fired that asshole Tilden today. I'm retired. And besides, you don't have a team. They all flew home in their jets to their castles. 
[10]We're gonna finish the season anyway. All of us owners decided. We're gonna use replacement players. You're a bunch of greedy bastards, aren't you? 
[11]Us, greedy?! What about the god damn players?! I got the highest payroll in the N.F.L. and they still want more! That's because you've been bottle-feeding straight cash to these big babies for years. 
[12]No team owner in their right mind is gonna give back those T.V. revenues. 
[13]All we promised Fox was twenty-two guys with a pulse every Sunday. But think about it, Jimmy. We got a great opportunity here! We got a chance to put a team on the field that plays the game just for the love of it. Like we used to play it. We also used to play without face guards. 
[14]Jimmy, I'm really dying. The doctor says I'll be gone by Superbowl Sunday. Help me bring a winner back to D.C. You did it for me once before. You can do it again. Listen: I golf once a week with the President of the United States. I walk my grandkids to school every day. I got a    young wife who will    fuck me any time I want,    which frankly, isn't    too often, but it's    comforting to know it's    there. I don't need    it. 
[15]Come on. Wouldn't it be fun? A bunch of poor nobodies who play to win instead of a bunch of bitchy millionaires? You can put it together, Jimmy. Player's love you. They always have. 
[16]Tell me you're gonna do it. Shut up, I'm thinking. Okay. Here's the deal: you let me recruit who I want, with no interference? 
[17]Absolutely. I'm talking anybody I want. No exceptions. And no interference with my coaching, either, like you used to. 
[18]Sure, Jimmy, sure. And one more thing: no more Notre Dame stories. You start telling me Notre Dame stories and I pull your plug personally.   I swear to God. 
[19]Deal. 
[20]Shane 'Footsteps' Falco? This is what you're going to build an offense around? 
[21]Christ, Jimmy, I ask you to build me a team based on balls and the first player I see is Footsteps Falco?! He's got as much natural talent as any quarterback in the league. 
[22]And he's got the happiest feet I've ever seen! All he needs is a shot of self-confidence. He's our quarterback. That's the way it is. 
[23]What about a safety? We got two a days starting tomorrow and a game in five days! And we still don't have a safety?! 
[24]I called a friend of mine who just happens to be the Governor of Maryland. Terrific, the Governor is going to play safety? 
[25]Don't worry about it. 
[26]Turn it off. This is going to kill me. 
[27]I'll give you 50 thousand dollars for a bite of that steak! Alright, listen up: There have been a lot of rumors about the regular players crossing the picket lines. They are not rumors. Many union players have now seen the error of their ways and are coming back in 
[28]Now that's a hit! 
[29]Where are we gonna keep him? In the stadium. We'll fix up something comfortable for him and he'll get his exercise by kicking the shit out of N.F.L. receivers. 
[30]How did you pull that off? How else? With your money. 
[31]Take this cow piss out of here. 
[32]Let's keep 'em all. The hell with the regulars. You've got to take the union players back once the strike ends. It's part of the collective bargaining agreement. 
[33]The hell I do! I'm dying! Let 'em sue me. They'll do worse than 
[34]God damn 'em! Then you got to beat Dallas. The whole country will be watching. All those millionaires down there deserve to have their noses rubbed in it. Ed, let's be honest: beating Dallas is gonna be a hell of a trick. 
[35]You can pull it    off. You proved that    winning doesn't have to    look pretty. These     boys are hungry for it,    Jimmy. 
[36]There's nothin' more dangerous in all of sports than a hungry team. I remember back in '47, we were playing Nebraska in the mud... Ed, I'm begging you -- no Notre Dame stories. 
[37]Okay, Jimmy, okay. But you beat Dallas for me, and then I'll go gently into that night.

dialogues.AL:
[1]Good evening from the Big O here in Washington D.C. where the mighty Dallas Cowboys take on the Cinderella Washington 'Scabskins' as they have come to be known. Hi, I'm Al Michaels and we are witnesses to a unique matchup tonight as Shane Falco and a contingent of strike players go up against the entire regular squad of the Dallas Cowboys. Yes, you heard right: every Cowboy has now crossed the picket line, some as late as this afternoon, and they will all play tonight. Can a rag tag group of hasbeens and castoffs stand up to what was once called America's team? And what about the strike itself? It has been so ineffective that many predict it will be over before this game ends. Stay tuned as Boomer and Dan join me for strike ball, D.C. style. 
[2]That    is one    very big leg    on Lou    Pacifico. He's    a big    reason why this    strike    team is two and    0. 
[3]Easy, guys. 
[4]That's the end of the 
[5]Okay, let's join Chris Berman with our half- time show. Chris? 
[6]What's wrong with you guys?! 
[7]Stop it! 
[8]... at nine-forty Eastern time, the agreement was reached, and except for this upcoming second half, the strike is history. 
[9]Well, this is a first. Shane Falco seems to be... 
[10]Here we go, first and ten for the Redskins. Twenty-four zip Dallas. 
[11]Whoa! Flags fly everywhere! I've never seen anything like this! 
[12]First and ten at the Cowboy twenty and I'm telling you, we are looking at a totally different team here in the second half. 
[13]I love when you guys agree. 
[14]Touchdown, Skins!     What a fluke! 
[15]... one minute twenty remaining, and even though Dallas didn't score, they sure ate up a lot of the clock. 
[16]And for Pacifico, that's anything up to sixty-five yards. 
[17]That's good for twelve yards. The clock stops on the first down. The Redskins have no time- outs left. 
[18]Wilkinson throws it away, and with twelve seconds remaining, the Redskins will try a forty-eight yard field goal to tie it up. That's almost a chip shot for Pacifico. 
[19]It's a fake! Falco has it! 
[20]Falco scores! 
[21]Wait a minute. Wait a minute. We've got a flag down.

dialogues.EVANS:
[1]You won't need a center. How you doin', Reese? 
[2]Bored and ready to retire. I'm just looking for one more hit. One more really good hit. What about the strike? 
[3]Hell, I'm rich. I got no complaint with Mister O'Neil. I just want a chance to play one last time. 
[4]Shit, I'd rather go out with a broken leg than sitting on the bench. Welcome to the new Washington Redskins. Let's find Reese somebody to play with. 
[5]Nice. Try a roll to the right. 
[6]You okay? 
[7]Remember to nod your head on the snap. 
[8]For    when Murray's in. The    deaf kid. Hello? He    needs to look at you on    the snap. 
[9]Shane, we got to move! 
[10]He's too far outside for me to get to him. Bring him down and sit on him. 
[11]Shane... 
[12]I'm proud of you, kid. 
[13]Hell, I'm retiring. I have thirty minutes of football left in my whole career. I'm homicidal! 
[14]Are you okay? 
[15]Come on, Shane! 
[16]That's the one I was looking for. I can retire in peace now.
dialogues.LEE:
[1]Not bad, Coach. You look great. Why don't you work out at left tackle? 
[2]You got it. 
[3]I always ate before a big match. I need the bulk. 
[4]No it's not. 
[5]What did you call me?! 
[6]I'm gonna kick your black ass... 
[7]Suppose like, you don't feel good. Or you're hurt or something like that. Then what? 
[8]I don't feel good. 
[9]I'll help this time. 
[10]What? 
[11]You think that's worth a shoe deal? Stop with the lovefest! Let's get the goddamn ball back and win this thing! 
[12]You'll score, too, with a Cadillac from Coleman Cadillac. It's a big car for a big man. 
[13]You'll score, too, with a Cadillac from Coleman's Cadillac. It's a big car for a big man. 
[14]You'll score, too, with a Cadillac from Coleman Cadillac. It's a big car, for a big man. 
[15]What?! I'm not doing it again! Who are you, Orson Welles?! This is nuts! 
[16]I'm so sorry, Shane. I'm sorry, everybody.
dialogues.JAMAL:
[1]Get out of the way! else Don't look at him! He don't like being looked at, god damn it! No eye contact! 
[2]You know I don't take that shit. 
[3]You all put that car back. 
[4]Put the car back. Gently. 
[5]No, it's not. 
[6]That's your ride, ain't it? 
[7]Move his car back. 
[8]No I'm not. And quit messing with my man here. That includes his ride. 
[9]Bastards. 
[10]Don't be messing with my brother... 
[11]That's to the right... right? 
[12]You better be quiet, Shane, they'll hear you. 
[13]Oh. You said it was to the right, didn't you? 
[14]Man, that's ripe! 
[15]One touchdown ain't gonna help, Shane.
dialogues.ANDRE:
[1]Be cool. 
[2]We're the people who take care of the quarterback. We're the guards. 
[3]Let's go to practice, Shane. 
[4]That's where I stand. 
[5]Come on, man, that's my spot in the huddle. 
[6]... Fat fucking nip! You don't know shit! 
[7]You heard me, you tub a rice shit! 
[8]You ain't kickin' jack shit... 
[9]Yeah, but he took my place... 
[10]No, it's to the left. 
[11]Oh, God! 
[12]What's that mean? 
[13]You're the one, you're the one, you're the one... 
[14]Is that true?
dialogues.BOOMER:
[1]But you have to admit, Dan, Falco is proving to be the real thing. 
[2]Here we go... 
[3]Dan, I think Butler's hit on Falco was late, to tell you the truth. 
[4]There's still a whole half left, Dan. And remember, Falco is proving to be a second- half quarterback. 
[5]Those big, fat boys in the trenches get awful tired. You ought to know that, Dan. 
[6]He started it. 
[7]I did not! But you are! 
[8]Yeah, you would say that. 
[9]Hell,    Al, he's necking with    a cheerleader! I've    done a little of that    in my time. 
[10]Hey, Dan, what are they 
[11]Unbelievable! One Washington player had a Cowboy in what appeared to be a police choke hold. 
[12]Absolutely, Al. The Redskins are playing like there's no tomorrow, because, hey, there isn't! 
[13]Total luck there, Al. Makes up for the perfect ones they drop. 
[14]And it looks like Falco cannot answer the bell. He's still on the bench
dialogues.DAN:
[1]But the fact is, a kicker does not an offense make. I think tonight the Scabskins will have a very rude awakening. 
[2]Well, Boomer, no, I don't have to admit anything. 
[3]What pursuit! Butler never gave up on him. That's a 270-pound guy who moves like a halfback. 
[4]Well, of course you do. You were a wimp quarterback. 
[5]Al, the battle is being fought and won in the trenches. You can't expect a bunch of pick- up players to stand up to a professional pass rush like the Cowboys. 
[6]You got to be kidding. 
[7]I did not! You called me fat! 
[8]It's about time. I say let the professionals back on the field. The fans deserve nothing less. 
[9]The players are not supposed to fraternize with the cheerleaders. 
[10]I see at least five flags... no six! 
[11]I gotta agree with you on this one. The surprising thing for me is how ineffectual the Cowboys have been in this half. I mean, they look totally intimidated. 
[12]Maybe not so lucky. Falco is down. 
[13]They just need to get the ball in field goal range.
dialogues.WILSON:
[1]Hey, man, I do what my union says. 
[2]Let me tell you something: I'm a big man, you see? 
[3]There are some days when I am so beat up, that I cannot dress my own big ass. I asked management for a valet or some shit to help me dress and they said no way. So, fuck 'em! 
[4]Shit, I'm goin' to Vegas. 
[5]Who the fuck are you? 
[6]Kiss my ass. 
[7]My windshield! You crazy motherfucker! 
[8]My car! 
[9]No!   Stop! 
[10]Come on, help me, god damn it! 
[11]You are gonna pay for this.
dialogues.CLIFFORD:
[1]What else? 
[2]Get out of here. I'm telling your mother you were talking like that. 
[3]Tell 'em I gotta work Saturday. And I'm watching the Redskins on Sunday. Ain't nothing stopping me from watching the Redskins on Sunday. No way that's gonna be 
[4]Pay me?    How much? 
[5]Ray, who the fuck is on the phone?! 
[6]Oh God, there's Eddie Martel! And Wilson Jones! I love Wilson Jones! Yo, Wilson! Yo, player! 
[7]I know, Coach, I know. Okay. I assume that you have touched a woman in a romantic way, have you not? 
[8]Oh yeah, Coach, sure. In a, you know, romantic way. Good. From here on out, you touch this football, all the time... ... just like you touch your girl friends. I better not see you without this ball. You understand? 
[9]Coach, wait! Can I still like touch my girl friends if I don't, you know, let go of the ball? Yes, Clifford, if you can manage that, absolutely. 
[10]I got Wilson Boone's locker, man. Do you believe that shit?
dialogues.ROLAND:
[1]Cut right on me, now. Right on me. 
[2]Not right on me, goddamn it! 
[3]Thank you, Lord! 
[4]Actually, less than two minutes. I was a rookie third round pick in '93. We were playing Atlanta in the home opener. Near the end of the first quarter, they sent me in, I took a screen pass over the middle and got hit by both linebackers. Simultaneously. One a 
[5]I've been teaching high school football for five years. It's not a bad life. I'm good at it. There are some days when I actually love it. But for one more shot at this? Shit. I'd give it all up. This time, they're gonna have to take me out in a box. 
[6]For my last play in football, I'll take that block. 
[7]I thought you were going to score. What happened? Did you slip? 
[8]That's what I thought. 
[9]It was a dream come true. Go kick some ass for me.
dialogues.AUGUSTINE:
[1]Did they win or lose?! 
[2]That has the distinct tonal quality of a loss. 
[3]Nice medicine for a loss. Keeps us calm. Makes us not so sad. Keeps us on an even keel. Gives us some perspective, doesn't it? And we'll save the winning medicine for next Sunday, won't we? 
[4]Sounds exciting. 
[5]We'll want to talk to coach now, won't we? 
[6]Better? It always makes you feel better when you fire someone, we know it does, don't we? Yes... 
[7]Here we go. Nice fat little hits. 
[8]You used to love asparagus soup. They say that when the taste buds go, you're at the beginning of the end. I want to keep Falco after the strike ends. As Martel's back-up.
dialogues.REPORTER:
[1]But you're already one of the highest paid players in the game. The fans just don't see the point of a player like you striking. 
[2]As president of the Players' Association, what does your presence mean here, Mister Lindell? 
[3]But where have you been? What have you been doing to make a living? 
[4]Coach, what will be your strategy against New York this Sunday? 
[5]Bob, I'm standing in front of Redskins owner, Edward Frances O'Neil's home and all we know right now is that the Washington player previously known as Ray Smith is in fact Earl Samuel Wilkinson... 
[6]... the All Pro Miami Safety who was serving five to seven years in the Maryland state penitentiary for three counts of aggravated assault. As you may recall, one of those counts was against a Baltimore City police officer and resulted in that officer being hospitalized for quite some time. 
[7]No, Bob, but rumor has it that the National Football League Player's Association had something to do with it. 
[8]Mister Matheson, what are the sticking points in the negotiations as far as the owners are concerned?
dialogues.LINDELL:
[1]I have just left a meeting with representatives of the owners and I am sad to say that they have refused the players' final demands which center around a rise in the current salary cap. 
[2]Very simply, support for these fine players and union men. Washington D.C. is the home of freedom and the collective bargaining agreement. I am here to remind all Americans that the owners are no better than the robber barons of the Nineteenth Century. They have blatantly gone out and hired scabs, which is against all principles of our Constitution and the Declaration of Independence and probably even the Emancipation Proclamation. 
[3]And here come the Scabskins now! 
[4]Don't be asking    for no autographs from    the real players and    then go in and watch    the scabs! 
[5]That is not the message we want to send our children! 
[6]... because it's about brothers, and brotherhood and standing together against the oppressors. That's why I am so grateful to our Teamster brothers who have joined us here today in New York to protest the greed squad known as the N.F.L. owners. 
[7]I think that Mister Matheson here, and myself, are very close to an agreement that will put the 'pro' back in pro-football.
dialogues.PILACHOWSKI:
[1]... Six phone lines with internet access on two: One for defense and one for offense. 
[2]Except for a kicker. We definitely need a kicker. A place kicker over a punter. 
[3]Okay. Here's the list of every player cut this past season. What we would like to do is... Those people? list Most of them were cut because they were shitty. We're going to go another way here. I've done some scouting since I retired. On an ad hoc basis, of course. And what I have here is a list of people I've kept an eye on. They've all played football somewhere, but only a few in the pros. And they've all got something... unique to bring to the game. We're gonna take these people and try to put together a winning team. And if nothing else, they should be fun to watch. 
[4]Oh my God. That's disgusting! How you doin', Mickey? 
[5]You're not serious. I met Mickey in Hawaii. When he was even bigger. He's a Sumo wrestler. That means he's an expert at pushing people around. That's what pass blocking is, Leo. 
[6]walk I'll trade you for a tackle who's gonna play in a diaper. 
[7]What are you, crazy? Nobody eats right before a game.
dialogues.BANES:
[1]We thought we would skip special teams for the moment. 
[2]The thinking being that if we lose the toss, we have to be able to at least kick off. 
[3]I got a defensive end who's deaf!! 
[4]How can I coach a deaf man?! You don't have to... Brian Murray would have gone in the first round five years back if he hadn't been born deaf. I first saw him play right here in D.C. for Galludet College. He's a hell of an athlete. You won't have to tell him anything. 
[5]I can't believe it! I got to be able to communicate with him. Then learn to sign. Hey, look at it this way: He'll never get 
[6]Where did you play, Judge? Wait. Do I call you judge?
dialogues.BATEMAN:
[1]What area code is 703? 
[2]Hi, I'm Danny. 
[3]Thank's, Coach! 
[4]The ball. Okay, Coach. 
[5]Beautiful tackle, Shane! 
[6]Me, too, Reese!
dialogues.WALTER:
[1]Praise the Lord, Shane. 
[2]Walt Cochran. Offensive tackle. 
[3]Shane, will you witness with me? 
[4]Will you witness with me? For this upcoming practice. 
[5]Praise the Lord for giving us a way to eliminate, Shane. Why not talk to Him in the midst of performing his gift? 
[6]Heavenly Father, thank you for allowing us to pee the poisons from our systems. Please help us in today's practice to be strong and...
dialogues.WILKINSON:
[1]Smith. Ray Smith. I played at a junior college nobody ever heard of. What position did you play on defense, Judge? 
[2]Yeah, big fellow like you, that's what I would have guessed. 
[3]You know, maybe you can show me some of your technique, Your Honor. Maybe you can show me some of that toughness. 
[4]I can't wait. 
[5]Oooh... got me a judge! Man, that felt good! 
[6]Congratulations on what?
dialogues.COCHRAN:
[1]Coach McGinty, I'd like to lead the team in the pregame prayer. No. No praying. That's the problem with professional sports today: too much god damn praying. Five hundred dollar fine to the first man I hear praying. A lot of people are waiting for you to fall on your asses today. And guess what? You're going to. But I don't give a shit if you look funny out there. Or if you miss a block, or drop a pass, or trip over your own dick. This is professional. And the difference between professional and amateur, between playing for the Washington Redskins and Michigan State is simply... money. You are being paid to win. Not just to play. Not just to learn how to be good sports. Not for the alumni. You are being paid to win. I don't care how the fuck you do it. But I'm demanding it. Because those guys whose place you're taking have forgotten that simple fact. So, go win it. 
[2]You see. We should have prayed. 
[3]Oooooh... 
[4]He's huge! He's been beating the crap out of me all day! I feel like a rag doll out here. 
[5]I just want to say what an honor it is to play opposite you. And if it's not too much trouble, I would love to have your autograph. 
[6]Shut up! I'm gonna do it again 'cause it was fun!
dialogues.BUTLER:
[1]No problem. 
[2]I'm gonna autograph your body with bruises, you scab-ass son of a bitch! 
[3]How's that side feel? 
[4]That wasn't too smart. 
[5]He scratched my eyes out! 
[6]I can't believe you went for my eyes!
